context_meta.title: Allegheny Co. Dog Wardens Checking For Current Dog Licenses, Rabies Vaccinations
context_meta.summary: PITTSBURGH (KDKA) — Officials in Allegheny County will be checking up on pet owners over the next two weeks to make sure they have up-to-date licenses and rabies vaccinations for their dogs. The Pennsylvania Department of Agriculture says state dog wardens will be conducting dog license and rabies vaccination checks throughout the month of May. Checks will take place in Allegheny County from May 14 to May 18 and continue from May 21 to May 25. Dog wardens will also be canvassing in Indiana and Lawrence counties from May 14 to May 18. They will be in Fayette County from May 28 to May 31. Pet owners with dogs over the age of 3 months must have a dog license by Jan. 1 of each year. Additionally,

context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Halifax woman finds Staffordshire bull terrier after three years
context_meta.summary: A woman has been reunited with her beloved dog more than three years after he disappeared. Levi Jade Spark, from Halifax, spent months trying to find her pet Junior, who went missing in February 2015 while being looked after by her great aunt in Mixenden, West Yorkshire.  The mother of one had given up any hope that she would ever see him again. But then one day she suddenly saw a Facebook post about a dog that had been found on Swalesmoor Road - four miles away from where Junior had vanished years earlier. The 22-year-old went to visit the lost dog on May 7 and confirmed it was Junior. The Staffordshire bull terrier crossed with an American bulldog was even wearing the same collar he had on

context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: A competitive team sport, for your dog
context_meta.summary: Flyball, in which four-dog teams compete in a choreographed relay race, is a weekend ritual for many, as sacrosanct as youth soccer or bowling for others. Flyball, a sport in which four-dog teams compete in a carefully choreographed relay race, is a weekend ritual for many people, as sacrosanct as youth soccer or bowling leagues are to others. Aside from the occasional ribbon, trophy or title that its recipient cannot fully appreciate (“Iron Dog,” “Master Champion”), the main rewards are the sense of community that Flyball fosters and — perhaps more important — the emotional partnership it builds between people and their pets. “Once you work with a dog, that bonds the two of you to a whole other level,” said Dr. Peter J. Lotsikas, a veterinarian and founder of Skylos Sports Medicine of Maryland, which specializes in treating orthopedic problems in dogs.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Hunting dog sinks its teeth into the neck of a wild pig in the USA
context_meta.summary: The savage moment a hunting dog sinks its teeth into a wild pig has been captured on a GoPro attached to its head. Shocking footage shows the dog running across a field and through water before catching the black pig. The clip, believed to be filmed in the USA, shows the dog dashing past other hounds to get to the pig. The pair tumble into a stream where the continue their fight to the death. Other dogs run and join in the attack. Hunters then appear and hold the pig down as the dogs continue to bite intoit. Two men then pat one of the dogs before sending it away. The shocking footage has racked up more than 14,000 views since it was posted on YouTube and has won praise from hunting enthusiasts.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: The ‘killer scorpions’ and poisonous frogs being mailed to China to feed exotic pet craze
context_meta.summary: Exotic animals including ‘killer scorpions’ and poisonous frogs are being mailed into China alive in regular parcels to feed a boom in owning alternative pets. The influx of banned insects and animals - which also include snakes, spiders, beetles and tortoises - has prompted fears that the new arrivals could harm China's biodiversity and farming output, or even be used by terrorists. Illicit traffickers evade customs inspectors by only packing small amounts of live animals each time, but the overall trade has been described as "rampant" by Chinese media. Authorities have issued warnings against importers and enforced tighter border controls in response to the trade, which has also caused alarm among animal rights groups. More than 42,000 mail and parcel deliveries of banned animals and plants were seized at Chinese ports last year, and harmful species were identified in 5,147 of them, China's General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine said. Chinese pet owners are driving a boom in illicit imports of everything from scorpions to beatles A statement posted on the China Quality news website, which is affiliated to the organisation, added: "They may have no natural enemies in China, so they will likely reproduce in great numbers and pose a serious threat to indigenous species and harm China's ecology, biodiversity and agricultural production if they are not properly taken care of." Customs officials also identified that some species, such as the Brazilian “killer scorpion”, poison dart frogs and poisonous snakes, could be dangerous to the public, or even be "used by terrorists", the China Daily said. Pet owning was banned in China under revolutionary leader Mao Tze-tung, who believed it was a bourgeoisie hobby. But the rise in urbanisation and Western trends has seen dogs and cats being welcomed into many homes. Families often lavish huge amounts of cash on their pets in China, where there are pet hotels, pet cemeteries and even facilities for pet acupuncture. However, Chinese animal lovers are now becoming more adventurous in the species they want to own. Reports in China suggest there is a growing trend for monkeys, foxes and reptiles being traded in China. Pa Chongle, a store run at South China Agricultural University which breeds lizards and snakes, generates 20,000 yuan (£2,300) a month through sales, student Li Yiqun said. "A lizard costs from 100 to 600 yuan (£12- 70) and a snake from 250 to 800 yuan (£29-93) and we usually sell them when they are a month old," Mr Li told The Telegraph. He said most of the animals at Pa Chongle, which roughly translates to 'Crawl Lovers', are sold to "young white collar workers". The cross-border trade in animals is tightly regulated under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), which China has signed. Animal welfare activists say the illegal transportation of animals can be brutal and cause massive harm to the eco-system where the animal was taken from. Sun Quanhui, from World Animal Protection, said: "Driven by Chinese demand for having wild animals as pets, each year tens of thousands of wild animals are forced to leave their natural habitat areas and become victims of the wild animal trade. "These animals are mistreated repeatedly during the capture, transportation and trade process. Batches have died, and those which are lucky enough to survive have lost their freedom and have no way back to their natural habitat." Wendy Higgins, from the Humane Society International, said animals endured "stress, malnutrition, dehydration, and long periods of confinement" during the transportation. "And for those who do survive, their suffering can continue as a pet because most people have no idea how to provide the complex environmental or dietary needs of these animals," Ms Higgins added. "Exotic wild animals belong in the wild where they can thrive in the freedom of their natural environment. Their home is not in our home." Despite the legal and ethical concerns over cross-border trading of wild animals, The Telegraph found many foreign species being sold openly on the Chinese Internet, including turtles from Brazil, Arctic foxes from the "North Pole" and widow spiders from Laos. The spider dealer offered to mail the arachnid from his store in Ningbo, in China's east, to Beijing, within three days, once payment of 90 yuan (£10.50) was received. "They are definitely from Laos because there are no males in China, so reproduction is impossible," the dealer told The Telegraph. When asked how he got the spider into China, he said: "We have our own sources". Additional reporting by Christine Wei

context_meta.summary: Q: I work at a pet-friendly company where people are allowed to bring their dogs. My co-worker “Mandy” has a golden retriever, and I have grown very fond of him. I feel so sad for both of them, but I'm not sure how to communicate with Mandy during this difficult time. Do you have any suggestions? A: Kudos to you for being sensitive to your co-worker's grief. context_meta.title: Downtown Muskegon dog park celebrates grand opening
context_meta.summary: MUSKEGON, MI -- Gloomy weather didn't stop pet owners from attending the opening of a new dog park in downtown Muskegon. Downtown Muskegon PetSafe Bark Park, located at 793 W. Western Ave., opened Saturday, May 12. Pet owners and community members came out to celebrate the anticipated event. "This is really nice," said Heidi Adams, who attended the opening with her 6-year-old black labradoodle, Bella. "It's a beautiful area to come and socialize." Bark Park includes two areas, a small dog area and a large dog area, both with grassy fields that are fenced in. context_meta.summary: A dog who ran away from home four years ago has been miraculously reunited with her family. context_meta.title: Prescription pets: 'I got a doctor's note to fly with my dog'
context_meta.summary: Going through an airport with Joan gives everything a surreal quality. When we got to JFK in New York one morning a few months ago, the harried pace of checking in and security was slowed because everyone wanted to spend time with her. Sometimes she stopped for a drink of water or to make eye contact with a baby. When we boarded our plane to San Francisco, a fellow passenger was taking selfies with Joan and sending them to his wife before we even took off. At one point I fell asleep and woke up to find him cradling her like a baby and cooing into her ears. Turbulence, which usually makes me turn to the drinks trolley, was a breeze: I just held her. context_meta.title: Life after the lab: State laws give research animals second chances
context_meta.summary: Ringo the beagle loves all the things every dog would: Running in the yard, rides in the car and the frequent snack. "He's just so happy to sit right in your lappy," his owner, Amy Bleich, an engineer in Edgewater, Maryland, said. You'd never know that Ringo, now five years old, had lived the entire first two years of his life inside a small cage at a nearby medical laboratory. When he was first adopted by the Bleich family in 2015, he was nervous around people and other dogs, and thrown off by the feel of grass beneath his paws and cool gusts of wind under his floppy ears. Dogs like Ringo rarely seem to get a happy ending. A majority of dogs that have been subjects of medical research and experimentation

context_meta.title: Shocking pictures show ill pooches kept in appalling conditions after escaping the slaughterhouse
context_meta.summary: Around 10 million dogs are slaughtered for meat in China every year, and for those that are lucky enough to be saved from the dinner plate, many have to live in extremely poor conditions at self-funded animal shelters.   A British animal lover is now trying to save dozens of pooches destined to be slaughtered in China just weeks before the annual Yulin dog meat festival is set to take place.   Cindi McNeilregan, 44, said she was hoping to rescue around 100 dogs by bringing them from the Far East to United Kingdom. Ms McNeilregan, from Taunton, Somerset, is the founder of Rushton Dog Rescue. She visited the Chinese city of Chengdu, which is most famous for giant pandas, at the beginning of May.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Man whose pit bulls attacked, ran off with smaller dog pleads guilty to charges
context_meta.summary: BAY CITY, MI -- A Monitor Township man whose unlicensed pit bulls attacked and ran off with a neighbor's smaller dog has pleaded guilty to two misdemeanors. On May 9 -- the day his trial was to begin -- Jerry A. Lawler Jr., 48, appeared before Bay County District Judge Mark E. Janer and pleaded guilty to two counts of allowing a dog to bite a domestic animal. The charge is punishable by up to 90 days in jail and a $500 fine. In exchange, the prosecution dismissed two counts each of allowing a dog to stray, having a dog without a license, and having a dog without a rabies vaccination. Janer sentenced Lawler to one year of probation and ordered he pay $595 in fines and court costs, due June 1.

context_meta.title: The Daily Spike: What's in a name?
context_meta.summary: Fido! Molly! Rover! Ollie! Naming a new puppy or dog can be a lot of fun. Ever wonder how Spike got his name?   Canine Companions for Independece names their puppies using one letter of the alphabet for each litter of pups, from A to Z. So, you guessed it, Spike's siblings all have names beginning with “S.” I was honored to suggest that a puppy be named in honor of my late brother Kyle, whose nickname was Spike. My brother had paralysis and used a wheelchair for many years. And now I'm proud to have Spike, a Canine Companions puppy, by my side, learning how to become a future assistance dog for someone with a disability. For CCI dogs, each puppy's name is more than just a name — it's also a specific

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Why has older dog started using the deck for a toilet?
context_meta.summary: DEAR JOAN: We have a 13-year-old dog. He is a mix of Lab, hound, Australian shepherd and possibly other.He has always done his poop business on our lawn in the backyard. Recently, he has been doing it on our wood deck and cement patio. I go out with him and he is on the lawn and then suddenly goes to the deck and poops. We enjoy our deck in the summer so I am trying to figure out how to fix this or why he is doing this. I feel it is age related. Susan S., Fremont DEAR SUSAN: It could be age related. After all, we all develop some idiosyncrasies as we age. To be on the safe side, take him in for a check up with your vet, just to make sure there isn't a physical issue. It could just be a habit
